Expectation1: Take and record vital signs like temperature, pulse, and blood pressure
Situation1: The nursing assistant is on their morning rounds to take a patient's routine vital signs.
Expectation2: Arrive on time for scheduled volunteer shifts
Situation2: Several other volunteers can easily cover the first part of the shift if someone shows up a little late.
Story: I glanced at the clock as I finished recording Mrs. Lee’s blood pressure. My morning rounds as a nursing assistant were running behind; Mr. Patel’s room was next, and he always took extra time because he liked to chat. I knew I was supposed to be meticulous—every patient’s vital signs needed to be taken and logged before the nurses’ meeting. But my phone buzzed with a reminder: my volunteer shift at the community center started in fifteen minutes. I was expected to be on time, to set a good example, even though I knew the other volunteers could cover for me if I was late. Still, I felt the weight of both roles pressing on me. If I rushed through my rounds, I might miss something important for a patient. If I stayed, I’d let down the volunteer coordinator who counted on my reliability. My heart pounded as I stood in the hallway, torn between the needs of my patients and my commitment to the community center, unsure which responsibility should come first.
